9a6ad4a5-3bc6-4642-bf41-0b30b3aa47aa.question: A 7-year-old girl comes to the clinic because her parents noticed her face turned red since the day before and in the last few hours they have noticed red spots on her body. Upon examination, she is not feverish, with no alterations in her tonsils and ears, and normal cardiopulmonary auscultation. She presents a confluent maculopapular rash on both cheeks, sparing the upper lip, resembling "slapped" face. On her chest, she presents a reticular, lace-like rash that is not itchy. What is the most likely clinical diagnosis?

ea42ebae-40c4-49ab-8f7c-53968e117ee4.question: A 4-month-old infant presents to the emergency room with vomiting and lethargy. On examination, significant decrease in consciousness level stands out, with an inability to wake up despite stimuli. Auxiliary examinations highlight the presence of anemia, retinal hemorrhages at the fundus of the eye, subdural hematoma in the cranial CT, and a fracture at the back part of the third rib. Which of the following diagnoses do you consider most likely responsible for these injuries?:

options.B: Multiple injuries due to falling from the crib.
options.C: Chest trauma in infant with coagulation disorder.
options.D: Acute promyelocytic leukemia after performing bone marrow aspiration.

1cfa5ffc-2ccf-4fbc-8da6-4602c92f00ee.question: Referring to epidemic parotitis in childhood, indicate the false response:

options.A: The mumps virus only presents one immunotype and the human being is the only natural host.
options.B: The mumps vaccine is included in the MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine and the tetravalent vaccine and requires two doses.
options.C: Orchitis as a complication is more common in early childhood.
options.D: Pancreatitis can occur in parotitis with or without clinical involvement of the parotid glands.

b1e78572-c2ec-4f24-a251-0a9c37dccd49.question: Indicate the false answer regarding the clinic, diagnosis and treatment of cystic fibrosis:

options.A: Fibrosing colonopathy is a consequence of chronic diarrhea due to insufficient doses of pancreatic enzymes.
options.B: Liver disease is independent of genotype, although it is more associated with pancreatic insufficiency and meconium ileus.
options.C: The determination of fecal elastase 1 is the most useful test for the diagnosis of pancreatic insufficiency.
options.D: In infants, it can manifest as hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

4df5cbc7-c6a6-4cda-a550-f73841ffef47.question: In congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to the classic form of 21-hydroxylase deficiency, indicate the correct answer:

options.A: There is a defect in the synthesis of androstenedione.
options.B: It usually manifests itself in the neonatal period with salt-wasting syndrome and virilization in girls.
options.C: Maintenance treatment with hydrocortisone monotherapy is sufficient to control salt loss.

2dea7ced-39b4-45f9-b431-468d010d0f12.question: Regarding Fanconi anemia, indicate the incorrect answer:

options.A: Aplastic anemia is usually already present in the first few months of life.
options.C: The transplant of hematopoietic progenitors is the curative treatment, but it does not eliminate the risk of cancer.
options.D: Androgens usually produce a favorable but transient response.

f5c98e9c-f89c-499a-83d3-3e80c6b1ec9d.question: A 1-month-old infant is hospitalized and on a strict diet. Using the body weight method to calculate the daily maintenance fluid volume, the corresponding value for this patient will be:

0e6f3f41-0e26-432b-a41b-123e38db3787.question: Regarding prophylactic treatment with lithium in bipolar disorder, indicate the correct answer:

options.A: The margin between therapeutic and toxic doses is narrow.
options.B: Its use is safe during pregnancy.
options.C: The new antipsychotics have made their use practically obsolete.
options.D: Thiazide diuretics can decrease your blood rate and therefore their effectiveness.

c4e7c338-73a2-41b0-92ef-90bdc365ab4b.question: Which of the following antipsychotics requires routine blood counts during treatment due to an increased risk of agranulocytosis?:

8b1de10c-a069-432c-8c52-0e41738bb5b0.question: In a patient who is 85 years old with cognitive impairment and a depressive episode, indicate the antidepressant treatment that should be avoided:

0a512fe2-8178-4877-b665-c1992b58aa0d.question: In relation to hypomania, indicate which of the following characteristics is incorrect:

options.A: Hypomania is almost never a reason for consultation and should be sought in the anamnesis of depressive episodes.
options.B: The history of hypomania in a patient with a major depressive episode changes the diagnosis of depressive disorder and influences the therapeutic decision.
options.C: Patients with hypomania may feel more active and sociable, although their behavior is generally somewhat inappropriate.
options.D: These patients exhibit psychotic symptoms, such as delusions of grandeur.

7e1c8c34-4b90-4f2b-b68d-4372e5e3d7b2.question: A patient with a psychotic relapse who has started treatment with an antipsychotic that showed good response in the previous episode, comes to the consultation because of a feeling of motor restlessness that forces him to constantly move and prevents him from sitting still. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?:

options.A: Reduce the dose of the antipsychotic and add bromocriptine.

c819fb83-4cfb-434d-b04a-5be600879198.question: According to the DSM 5, body dysmorphic disorder belongs to the group of:

ff5b3b3b-1138-47ca-b88b-e0473098880a.question: To treat peripheral neuropathic pain, one of the following antiepileptic drugs could be used:

e288bc81-8300-4d6d-b9fe-9b3ecfe9e9ef.question: A 59-year-old man, married, with no psychiatric history, has progressively over the last two years shown notable irritability and apathy. He has been absent from his job several times and his performance has notably decreased. He has been reprimanded at work for insulting several clients or for unjustified absences. On weekends, he is a recreational leader with teenagers, where it is reported that he excessively jokes with the boys and a female leader has complained that he has made inappropriate insinuations. Up until now, there have never been behaviors of this type. His wife is very worried because he says strange things and is thinking about separating. His family doctor has performed a Mini-Mental cognitive test that is within the normal range and no significant memory deficits are apparent. What is the least likely diagnosis?

915edfe6-301d-40a4-adc2-0ca507fe543a.question: Indicate which of the following studies by CT can differentiate, in a wake-up stroke, the cerebral area at risk of potentially recoverable ischemia from the area of already established irreversible infarction:

7ee22cf1-835c-4cac-b8ca-4539ca70301b.question: Indicate which of the following clinical manifestations would make you doubt a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease:

options.B: Falls within the first two years of symptomatology.
options.C: Presence of a behavioral disorder during REM sleep.

67102b93-5ea6-48f9-8cdc-6a21a2572ece.question: A 65-year-old patient with a history of regular alcohol consumption is attended to in emergency due to a clinical picture evolving over 24 hours of fever, headache, neck stiffness, and progressive deterioration of consciousness level. A cranial CT is performed which is normal and subsequently a lumbar puncture is performed which shows a CSF with pleocytosis (1500 cells/µl), hyperproteinorrachia (325 mg/dl), and hypoglucorrhachia (< 10 mg/dl). The most correct initial empirical antibiotic treatment among the following is:

07536b53-369e-46e2-b40a-b4faf473c3be.question: A 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and anxiety goes to the emergency room because suddenly that afternoon she started having difficulty with language production ("I wanted to say table but couldn't") and uncontrollable "jolting" movements in her right arm and leg. After two minutes, the movements subsided and she could speak normally. She was aware of the situation at all times. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.B: Transient ischemic attack in the right carotid territory.

d68ee8c1-c6dd-4277-b98c-1eb18e3c335e.question: A 64-year-old man who has been experiencing a progressive language disorder for a year. This is characterized by difficulty in finding words. He uses many umbrella terms and circumlocutions. He understands perfectly and his speech is relatively fluid except for anomia pauses. The difficulty to repeat long sentences is noticeable in the examination. He has no memory disorders or evident behavior problems. What is the most probable diagnosis?

options.A: Nonfluent variant of primary progressive aphasia, probably due to frontotemporal dementia.
options.B: Logopenic variant of primary progressive aphasia, probably due to Alzheimer's disease.
options.D: Unspecific dysnomia in the elderly patient.

954f8eda-e80c-48f4-9d23-7ffbfb181c2f.question: A 75-year-old woman is consulting for a condition of stabbing pain that runs across her right lip and nostril. She is unable to wash her face or brush her teeth due to the pain it causes, which she describes as an electric shock. She reports no pain when sleeping. Choose the correct answer:

options.A: The diagnosis corresponds to a paroxysmal hemicrania.
options.B: The treatment of choice is phenytoin.
options.C: The most likely cause is a compression of the VII pair in its cisternal path.
options.D: It can be treated with radiosurgery, but with a risk of recurrence.

100920d7-abb3-4d6e-9dc0-4730020d1efa.question: After a traffic accident, you attend to an injured person. The patient opens his eyes to call, but only utters words that are inappropriate. In the motor examination, he locates pain in the right limbs but extends when stimulating the left limbs. How would you describe their situation according to the Glasgow Coma Scale?

7177a2fa-3493-4eb2-8f17-767466ba5f99.question: Which of the following is not a main feature of frontotemporal dementia?

options.C: Rapid onset and progression of the disease.

7f1493c9-fad8-467a-9eb1-c11d5cfc5fe5.question: In relation to restless legs syndrome in older patients, indicate the incorrect answer:

options.B: Iron deficiency is considered a risk factor for its occurrence.
options.C: Its prevalence increases from the age of 70.
options.D: It is more common in males than in females.

056d4027-fda2-4e09-8660-10e6321734be.question: A 73-year-old patient with a history of chronic kidney disease exhibiting a case of 5 days of fever, headache, and confusion, accompanied by a tonic-clonic epileptic seizure. The clinical condition at the time of the assessment is good and the physical examination is normal. Tests highlight leukocytosis of 18,000/µl with 92% neutrophilia, normal red series and platelets; creatinine 2.3 mg/dl, eGFR 32 ml/min and CRP 15 mg/L (VN<5). The cranial CT does not show alterations. The CSF shows a clear liquid with 200 leukocytes/µl (60% lymphocytes), glucose 80 mg/dl, proteins 85 mg/dl (VN<50), ADA 25 IU/l (VN<15); the Gram stain of the CSF shows no microorganisms. What treatment would you recommend at this time?

options.B: Aciclovir plus isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide.

c7a7c2bc-f0da-4f6a-b3db-d8e97d303be1.question: 15-year-old male, admitted after being run over in the street, ending up ejected. He is admitted conscious and oriented, with intense pain in the left hemithorax and dyspnea. Physical examination reveals blood pressure 90/60 mmHg, heart rate 130 bpm, baseline oxygen saturation 90%, respiratory rate 35 rpm. There is entire loss of breath sounds in the left hemithorax and dullness to percussion. Chest X-ray reveals multiple left rib fractures and massive ipsilateral pleural effusion. Placement of a pleural drain is indicated, with an output of 1700 cc of hematic fluid. What is the decision that needs to be made?:

options.A: Establish non-invasive mechanical ventilation and request a blood transfusion.
options.B: Analgesia, oxygen therapy, request blood transfusion and indicate an urgent surgical intervention.
options.C: Orotracheal intubation, request blood transfusion and observation for, in case of worsening, indicate surgical intervention.
options.D: Orotracheal intubation and execution of an urgent CT scan for precise assessment of the injuries.

96d7efcf-63d8-452a-be59-9586a4da405c.question: In a patient in a septic shock situation with a manageable infectious focus, which of the following statements is true?:

options.A: Focus control should only be attempted once the patient has achieved hemodynamic stability and is not dependent on vasopressors.
options.B: The control of the infection will be carried out after administering at least two doses of antibiotics.
options.C: The control of the focus will be carried out as soon as possible.
options.D: If the septic shock situation has been progressing for more than 12 hours, controlling the source will no longer be beneficial for the patient.

f5ca1504-c04c-400f-897d-7c395cb99c71.question: A 56-year-old patient is found in a coma at his home. He has a history of high blood pressure and diabetes mellitus. He has no toxic habits or any other chronic diseases. He is being treated with irbesartan and empagliflozin. He shows no signs of malnutrition. He has a blood pressure of 110/60 mmHg, a heart rate of 110 bpm, a SatO2 of 90%, a capillary glucose of 120 mg/dl, and a respiratory rate of 7 rpm. What initial therapeutic approach do you think is the most correct?

options.B: Administer naloxone, flumazenil and hypertonic glucose.

b89425c4-83b4-4197-9c3a-07d1201c1e00.question: A 34-year-old male is involved in a traffic accident and is attended to at the scene. The medical personnel note that he is pale, sweaty, has a threadlike pulse with a blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg, a heart rate of 127 bpm, a respiratory rate of 28 rpm, and an oxygen saturation of 92%. He is infused with 20 ml/kg of crystalloids. During his transfer to the hospital, his vital signs temporarily improve and then deteriorate upon his arrival at the hospital. Indicate the correct answer:

options.B: Requires emergency blood transfusion (O Rh negative).
options.C: A possible blood transfusion should be prepared with cross-matching tests.
options.D: The infusion of another 20 ml/kg of crystalloids should be tested again.

55d1cf69-71f8-4409-97d1-9076e7771197.question: A 24-year-old woman with a history of migraines, undergoing treatment with propranolol and oral contraceptives, presents with severe dyspnea, hoarseness, skin rash, nausea, and vomiting 30 minutes after taking metamizol. She has a blood pressure of 90/40 mmHg and a SatO2 of 90%. The most correct initial treatment would be to administer:

9fdd7716-be1b-4b43-9d68-74681445d015.question: A 65-year-old patient suffered a fall three weeks ago with an anterior fracture-dislocation of the shoulder that was reduced in the emergency room. A sling was applied and it was recommended to be removed after 3 weeks. Upon removing the immobilization, an area of dysesthesia is observed circumscribed to the lateral region of the shoulder. The patient can perform abduction, but only reaches 15º. There is a magnetic resonance imaging study available in which the rotator cuff is unharmed. What is the most probable suspected diagnosis?

6ec539b2-71dc-4c08-b6a3-f293a84a41ac.question: In hand pathology, which of the following statements about Dupuytren's disease is incorrect?

options.A: It most frequently affects the ring and little fingers.
options.B: Conservative treatment with physiotherapy is minimally effective.
options.C: It is a thickening and retraction of the palmar aponeurosis.
options.D: It is more common in manual laborers.

201c1e6b-18ba-45d1-ab22-438141fd1126.question: In a posterior hip dislocation, indicate the incorrect answer:

options.A: The lower limb is in flexion, external rotation, and abduction.
options.B: An emergency reduction needs to be performed.
options.C: One of its possible complications is the necrosis of the femoral head.

8c93b5e7-0044-428b-895b-1f46c2f30790.question: A child suffers a distal tibial epiphysiolysis in a sports accident. When informing the parents about the prognosis, which of the following factors does not influence the risk of future deformity?:

options.A: Age and gender of the child.

a0771df2-4670-4128-b29a-8e1595f1d0cb.question: A 45-year-old patient who presents a first episode of lower back pain that has lasted 3 weeks and prevents him from living his normal life. He reports no trauma or underlying pathology. In the physical examination, there is no neurological deficit. What imaging test would be indicated?

options.A: As this is the first episode of lower back pain, only a simple X-ray of the lumbar spine is needed.
options.B: Magnetic resonance imaging, which provides more information about soft tissues and possible herniations.
options.C: CT scan, to better assess the bone structure and potential fractures.
options.D: There is no indication for imaging test.

800b9681-eaf0-4f85-9a7d-55c9ef634c75.question: A 40-year-old patient begins to feel discomfort in the right buttock after a long car trip. From that moment, he cannot tolerate prolonged sitting due to the recurrence of pain. He occasionally feels numbness in the right lower limb that disappears when he stands up. He has a magnetic resonance imaging study and hip radiograph which do not report anomalies. The examination of sensitivity and osteotendinous reflexes shows no alterations. The maneuvers of external rotation and resisted abduction, with the hip at 90º of flexion, reproduce the pain. The most likely diagnosis is:

7f7c1682-d5e5-4161-80a5-6642b31d53e1.question: Regarding the familial Mediterranean fever, it is false to say that:

options.A: The vast majority of patients present with a high fever suddenly.
options.B: The inflammatory episodes are brief and recurrent, with asymptomatic intervals.
options.D: They may experience chest pain due to pleuritis and/or sterile pericarditis.

649115df-d5a0-427e-8e97-ac9cda3160fd.question: Which of the following extra-articular manifestations is not characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis?:

47c76ad9-8e99-4285-a4b4-39a2c5d119d3.question: Regarding fibromyalgia, indicate the correct answer:

options.A: It has a prevalence in the general population between 5 and 10%.
options.B: The most common age of onset is over 50 years old.
options.C: There are multiple drugs approved for its treatment.
options.D: Fatigue is a very common symptom, affecting over 70% of patients.

d5998f73-11e6-4bef-ae13-c6d522bcdfa3.question: Regarding gout, it is false that:

options.A: The hypouricemic treatment should be initiated during the gout attack, as soon as possible.
options.B: The drug of choice is allopurinol, starting with low doses.
options.C: As a general rule, asymptomatic hyperuricemia should not be treated.
options.D: Around 50% of cases present as acute inflammatory monoarthritis of the first metatarsophalangeal joint.

09274bcc-1c32-4fa1-b234-744b0ca2d871.question: Among the following drugs for the treatment of osteoporosis, which one does not cause mandibular osteonecrosis or atypical femur fracture as a side effect?:

450c1643-08d1-47a0-b22e-63a1a97a3917.question: Which of the following is a priority objective in the therapeutic strategy for rheumatoid arthritis?:

options.A: Avoid frequent changes in treatment and avoid combinations of drugs.
options.B: Avoid unnecessary treatments in patients who, despite having symptoms, can maintain an acceptable daily activity.
options.C: The treatment should be early and intensive.
options.D: The same protocol should be applied to all patients.

8c02823d-0dd3-4c0e-8d5d-f6fe098946c5.question: In scleroderma, in order to diagnose lung disease in early stages, it is recommended to perform:

options.A: Pulmonary function tests and high-resolution CT scans every year.
options.B: Doppler echocardiogram and functional respiratory tests, only if the patient shows signs of respiratory and/or cardiac failure.
options.C: Respiratory function tests and Doppler echocardiogram, both with annual frequency.
options.D: Respiratory function tests and 6-minute walking test.

d06584eb-68c3-44f2-8121-cac2312a2378.question: A 45-year-old patient with a history of gastroesophageal reflux has been experiencing episodes of paleness in some fingers of the hands when exposed to cold for a year. She was recently prescribed prednisone at a dose of 20 mg/day due to joint pain and skin hardening in hands and arms. She has been experiencing malaise and severe headache for the last 48 hours, which is why she went to the emergency room. The examination only reveals rhythmic tachycardia at 100 bpm, no neurological focus is appreciated. The blood pressure is 200/110 mmHg. In the analysis, only a creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dl is notable. Indicate which of the following autoantibodies is best associated with the described process:

74646267-acd4-4018-a797-4dcc835922b0.question: A 2-week-old newborn, whose mother during pregnancy had unaffiliated polyarthralgias and who, after the first sun exposure, developed erythematous polycyclic skin lesions that resemble those of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus. Which of the following autoantibodies should be investigated?:

options.B: Neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) in the mother.

0cbc52ff-8364-4ee7-9669-ea6eb26f3a76.question: 27-year-old black woman who consults for the appearance of edema in the lower limbs, decreased urination, fever, and a malar rash in butterfly wings of 20 days of evolution. Analytically, creatinine 3 mg/dl stands out, leucopenia, hemoglobin 10.5 g/dl (normocytic normochromic), CRP 9 mg/dl and ESR 60 mm. Regarding the pathology that this patient presents, indicate the correct answer:

options.A: Anti-Sm antibodies are not specific to this pathology.
options.B: Anticentromere antibodies are detected in 90% of the cases.
options.C: The ANA (antinuclear antibodies) are detected in 50% of the cases.
options.D: Anti-double stranded or native DNA is correlated with the risk of nephritis.

99e66668-683e-4975-a39d-21fa4d2f934b.question: 75-year-old male, hypertensive under treatment with enalapril (20 mg/day), who reports general deterioration, bitemporal headache and mandibular claudication for 3 weeks. In addition, in the last few hours, he reports two episodes of fleeting amaurosis in the left eye. Physical examination reveals thickening and absence of pulse in the left temporal artery. Analysis: CRP 6 mg/dl (VN <1); hemoglobin 10.5 g/dl; ESR 92 mm. Normal chest X-ray. Considering the most likely diagnosis, mark the correct option regarding the treatment:

options.A: Rituximab should be administered, since glucocorticoids have been relegated to second-line treatment due to their side effects.
options.B: Tocilizumab has been shown to be effective in reducing relapses and the accumulated dose of prednisone in more than 50% of patients.
options.C: In the presence of ischemic symptoms, and to not worsen the patient's vascular risk, the use of glucocorticoids at doses higher than 30 mg/day should be avoided.
options.D: Along with boluses of glucocorticoids of 1 g/day, infliximab should be used as a first-line drug for induction into remission.

b2d4b709-df48-435c-a1d1-2d938f8df50e.question: A woman consults after having suffered a sexual assault 3 hours ago. Regarding post-exposure prophylaxis to HIV, indicate the incorrect answer:

options.B: A serology test for HIV must be carried out at the beginning and at the end of the prophylaxis.
options.C: The evidence for the usefulness of this treatment is not based on clinical trials.
options.D: The treatment is tenofovir and emtricitabine.

683cdfbc-2e81-4371-b21d-3ba8695f87c6.question: A 45-year-old patient was diagnosed with HIV infection three months ago, presenting at that time with CD4 45 lymphocytes/µl and an HIV-1 viral load of 500,000 copies/ml. At that time, he had a negative Mantoux test. He began treatment with an integrase inhibitor and two reverse transcriptase inhibitors, and a month later he had 25,000 copies and the CD4 had risen to 80/µl. He consults due to presenting a case of cervical lymphadenopathy and fever that has evolved over two weeks. The puncture of one of the lymph nodes shows acid-alcohol resistant isolated bacilli and epithelioid granulomas.

options.A: This refers to a ganglionic tuberculosis associated with an incomplete immune recovery.
options.B: The patient is not responding to treatment and is suffering from an opportunistic infection.
options.C: This is an opportunistic infection unmasked in the context of immune reconstitution.
options.D: The fact of having a negative Mantoux test rules out tuberculosis.

2571412a-af46-4edb-aea0-92bec7385c4b.question: Regarding severe bacterial meningitis caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, which of the following is false?:

options.A: In our environment, more than 50% of S. pneumoniae causing meningitis are resistant to penicillin.
options.B: The mortality rate of S. pneumoniae meningitis requiring ICU admission exceeds 30%.
options.C: The early initiation of treatment is essential for a good prognosis.
options.D: The use of dexamethasone improves functional and vital prognosis.

ca834221-1b3c-44dc-88ea-c3596e836dad.question: The monitoring of plasma drug concentrations is often done in clinical practice to adjust the dosage regimen of:

621580ec-8ddf-4b7a-a7c3-f2585e9fa8ab.question: The occurrence of torsades de pointes, due to prolongation of the QT interval on the electrocardiogram, is more likely to occur during antiarrhythmic treatment with drugs from the following group:

317f95b6-8f1e-4f19-9afe-97e0eda94c01.question: Indicate which characteristic corresponds to heart failure with preserved systolic function:

options.A: It is more common in young males.
options.C: The 1-year prognosis is good, with a mortality rate of less than 5%.
options.D: High blood pressure is the most associated pathology.

2a80ddde-1103-44ed-bf09-6d85636e274a.question: A 40-year-old man consults for slowly progressive exertional dyspnea for the past year. He has no toxic habits or significant medical history. He has not had chest pain. He presents with a harsh systolic murmur at the aortic focus, radiating to the cardiac apex and carotids. The ECG in sinus rhythm shows criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy and on the chest X-ray, a dilated aortic root is evident. Based on this information, what is the most probable diagnosis?

4631a37d-5eb8-405a-bc38-db7fd4dbb8fd.question: A 66-year-old male, diabetic and smoker, suffers from an anterior myocardial infarction with ST-segment elevation. The urgent coronary angiography shows a single lesion with acute occlusion in the proximal anterior descending artery, with a coated stent being implanted. At discharge, his electrocardiogram is in sinus rhythm with left bundle branch block (QRS 150 ms). The ejection fraction is 32%. Two months later, he comes for a review. Despite following optimal treatment, his functional class is III of the NYHA and the ejection fraction is 30%. What treatment should be offered to him at this time?:

options.A: Implant an automatic defibrillator and cardiac resynchronizer.
options.B: Repeat the coronary angiography due to suspicion of thrombosis in the implanted stent.
options.C: Add digoxin and loop diuretics and wait for the improvement of the ejection fraction in 6 months.
options.D: Refer him to a transplant unit to be included on the waiting list.

4835ec46-cedf-4704-9d76-3bcdda398d10.question: A 28-year-old woman with no cardiac history is admitted for syncope. She does not take drugs or consume toxins. She does not present with electrolyte imbalances. Her electrocardiogram shows a complete atrioventricular block with a ventricular rate of 30 bpm that requires the implantation of a permanent pacemaker. Based on this information, which of the following pathologies should be suspected?:

options.A: A rheumatic valve disease with mitral stenosis.
options.B: A pulmonary embolism with lung infarction.
options.C: A systemic infiltrative or inflammatory disease.

66aa0c08-b7c9-4bc7-abc6-7ba4fab97ef2.question: In relation to popliteal artery aneurysms:

options.A: When a wide popliteal pulse is suspected by palpation, ultrasound is the diagnostic test of choice.
options.B: The risk of aneurysm rupture is high.
options.C: The compression edema of the popliteal vein is the most frequent manifestation.
options.D: They are more common in women than in men at a ratio of 2:1.

01bc2df3-9f2a-4817-bbc9-eb366aeab8e4.question: A 63-year-old male with a history of hypertension, Sjögren's syndrome, and left iliofemoral revascularization (thromboendarterectomy). He has lost 10 kg and has severe abdominal pain after eating. The abdominal-pelvic angioCT shows severe stenosis of the celiac trunk and superior mesenteric artery. Indicate the false answer:

options.A: The physical examination often reveals signs of malnutrition and an abdominal murmur.
options.B: The treatment consists of thromboembolectomy with a Fogarty catheter.
options.C: The Doppler ultrasound (duplex) is a non-invasive examination useful for diagnosis.
options.D: Angioplasty with stent placement in the visceral trunks is a therapeutic option with a success rate of 80%.

568a0408-9797-43f3-87d4-201dacc128cf.question: A 53-year-old woman with a personal history of obesity and migraines. Her blood pressure has been measured on several occasions in both medical and nursing consultations with readings below 140/90 mmHg. However, she has purchased a certified blood pressure monitor and has been taught to use it correctly. She comes in showing blood pressure readings taken at her home over several weeks with values above 140/90 mmHg. Please indicate the correct answer:

options.A: The patient has secondary arterial hypertension.
options.B: He/she presents with masked arterial hypertension.
options.D: He/She presents with refractory arterial hypertension.

f7e58c5e-7a7c-4178-8eb9-d18217799d9e.question: A 64-year-old patient, who smokes 1 pack a day, with a personal history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and dyslipidemia, comes to the consultation reporting pain in the right calf when walking 200 meters and that improves with rest. What test would you perform first?

0bc25334-0470-4c80-a285-502ec7337eba.question: Among the different exploratory maneuvers of the heart, which one has the lowest diagnostic yield (sensitivity and specificity)?:

de705808-0c08-4ec8-94f8-17f01e5ec5b3.question: All the following therapies have shown to increase survival in the treatment of heart failure with depressed left ventricle ejection fraction except one. Indicate which:

96de5836-1986-48dd-b6c1-aafad2672a8e.question: Which of the following statements regarding right ventricle infarction is false?:

options.A: The infarction of the right ventricle can produce Kussmaul's sign.
options.B: The elevation of the ST segment in V4 is the most common presentation in the electrocardiogram.
options.C: The treatment includes volume expansion to preserve the preload of the right ventricle.
options.D: With echocardiography, we can observe hypokinesis and dilation of the right ventricle.

ec4c332a-e08c-4439-95ce-83984ec82d5f.question: Regarding thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease), indicate the correct answer:

options.A: It predominates in the female sex.
options.B: The presence of acute phase reactants determines the prognosis.
options.C: The evolution of the lesions largely depends on the cessation of smoking habit.
options.D: It is characterized as a segmental inflammatory thrombosis, atheromatous, which affects medium and small caliber arteries and veins.

131bb87a-c9d1-471e-b418-f61b4a0692ef.question: A 54-year-old male with persistent high cholesterol levels despite receiving treatment with 40 mg of atorvastatin (he did not tolerate the 80 mg dose due to myalgia) and having associated ezetimibe. He reports no history of hypertension or diabetes. He provides recent analysis with the following results: total cholesterol 302 mg/dl, LDL-cholesterol 270 mg/dl, HDL-cholesterol 32 mg/dl and normal triglycerides. In the physical examination, a BMI of 29 and a thickening at the level of the Achilles tendons stands out. With respect to the diagnostic suspicion and treatment, indicate the incorrect statement:

options.A: The diagnosis can be made through a genetic analysis.
options.B: If the condition is confirmed in the patient, we must conduct genetic testing on all first-degree relatives.
options.C: You could benefit from starting treatment with a PCSK9 inhibitor drug.
options.D: It is crucial to control all cardiovascular risk factors due to the association of this pathology with early cardiovascular events.

7cbc65d2-1cb4-47a0-a3e6-04d2cf3847eb.question: In the adult respiratory distress syndrome, it is true that:

options.A: Pulmonary edema is due to an increase in pulmonary capillary pressure.
options.B: Pulmonary edema is due to an injury to the alveolocapillary membrane.
options.C: The lung injury is due to a very negative pleural pressure.
options.D: The lung injury is primarily due to bronchoaspiration.

025a9a12-e950-4d4c-b181-73be1e4e0ea6.question: In a patient with small cell lung carcinoma, thoracic radiation therapy:

options.B: It is only used in superior vena cava syndrome.
options.D: It is recommended simultaneously with the first two cycles of chemotherapy.

a1399b8b-c367-4c34-8255-48e33644904d.question: After a month of standard treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis, a patient shows hyperuricemia in a control analysis, with a value of 12 mg/dl (upper limit of normality 7 mg/dl). The patient is asymptomatic. What would be your approach?

8c4302d9-00e4-4f09-bf51-d7aa5062716e.question: An 84-year-old woman, diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and undergoing home oxygen therapy, comes to the emergency room due to a worsening of her general condition, a fever of 39ºC, cough and purulent expectoration that has lasted for 5 days. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 90/70 mmHg, a heart rate of 125 bpm, a basal oxygen saturation of 86%, and a respiratory rate of 35 rpm. Auscultation reveals left basal hypoventilation. Her lab tests show 30,000 leukocytes (85% neutrophils). In the chest radiograph, a large left apical lung infiltrate and a moderate ipsilateral pleural effusion are detected. A thoracentesis is performed, yielding purulent pleural fluid, from which a culture is requested. What is the suspected diagnosis and the initial therapeutic approach?:

options.A: Community-acquired pneumonia. Pneumococcal antigenuria should be requested and broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage should be scheduled.
options.B: Pleural effusion under study. Antibiotic coverage should be carried out and serial radiological controls should be conducted.
options.C: Community-acquired pneumonia and left parapneumonic effusion. Antibiotic coverage must be applied and await the results of the pleural fluid culture to consider the placement of a pleural drain.
options.D: Community-acquired pneumonia and left parapneumonic pleural empyema. Antibiotic coverage should be carried out, pneumococcal antigenuria should be requested, and an urgent left pleural drainage should be performed.

76c397bc-ace2-423a-87db-b09004560588.question: In a patient with asthma, central bronchiectasis, and suspicion of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, what supplementary test would support the diagnosis of this condition?

b8c1e917-e7ca-4cc5-9442-b8ffd69eb4f9.question: A 59-year-old patient from sub-Saharan Africa, with frequent episodes of diminished consciousness due to chronic alcoholism. Consultation for night sweats, cough, and fever lasting several weeks. In the X-ray and thoracic CT, a cavitary lesion of 3.5 cm in diameter with a hydroaerial level in the right lower lobe is observed. What would be the incorrect answer?:

options.A: It is necessary to analyze samples of induced sputum to rule out tuberculosis.
options.B: An empirical treatment with metronidazole should be initiated.
options.C: If a specific pathogen is not isolated in the sputum, the presence of anaerobic germs is assumed.
options.D: If there is suspicion of immune compromise, a bronchoscopy with biopsy or CT-guided needle aspiration should be performed immediately.

78f9443c-53f4-4376-a02a-08151ad5effd.question: A 72-year-old woman with no notable medical history. Following a complicated kidney colic, a cystic lesion in the tail of the pancreas, measuring 2 cm, is accidentally found in an abdominal CT scan, along with multiple bilateral renal cystic lesions. Endoscopic ultrasonography shows a polycystic lesion made up of multiple vesicles with central calcification in the tail of the pancreas with no connection to the Wirsung duct. The fluid analysis is consistent with a serous cystadenoma. Among the following, which is the most appropriate approach regarding the management of this patient?:

options.B: Puncture guided by endoscopic ultrasonography and ethanolization of the same.
options.C: Follow-up of the injury through MRI.

ad10d650-3dfe-4f86-ac3e-f6a2a305678f.question: The diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome is primarily clinical and is based on compatible symptoms and the absence of warning signs or symptoms. Which of the following is not considered a warning sign or symptom?:

options.A: Onset of symptoms over the age of 50.
options.C: Positive for hidden blood in stool.

ac1af9c9-0c61-4803-90ce-c7ff1896cb50.question: An 83-year-old male who consults for a recurring episode of abdominal pain in the left iliac fossa, accompanied by diarrhea of up to 6 stools a day without pathological products, lasting 10-15 days. He does not report fever or general health impairment. A recent analysis shows no leukocytosis and he tested negative for occult blood in stool. Examination reveals mild pain on palpating the left iliac fossa without peritoneal irritation. He underwent a colonoscopy three years ago, which reported diverticula throughout the colon, more numerous in the left colon, without other associated lesions. Of the following, what would be the best course of action?

options.A: Perform an empirical treatment with antibiotics.
options.D: Refer to surgery to consider sigmoidectomy.

2ffe7065-69b4-4bb0-a2be-45faee4b2983.question: A 43-year-old man with no notable medical history presents with a ten-day history of jaundice of the skin and mucous membranes, dark urine, and pale stools. He reports no abdominal pain, weight loss, or other symptoms, except for generalized itching. He denies alcohol consumption. He's not taking any medications aside from occasional ibuprofen for muscle pain after physical exercise. His blood tests show an increase in bilirubin, primarily direct bilirubin. An urgent ultrasound shows a normal liver, gallbladder cholesterolosis, and no dilation of the bile duct, with no other notable abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Acute cholangitis due to biliary sludge.

d1c6e874-fa19-4100-bd2c-12578bc9e756.question: A 79-year-old woman with hypertension being treated with olmesartan attended a consultation due to watery diarrhea of 4 to 6 bowel movements a day for the past two months. Three months ago, she underwent treatment with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for three weeks due to sciatica. She underwent gastroscopy and colonoscopy, both without macroscopic abnormalities. Duodenal biopsies were normal, while in colon biopsies a chronic inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria with an irregular band of collagen immediately below the surface epithelium of the mucosa with a thickness greater than 10 mm and a number of intraepithelial lymphocytes > 20 per 100 epithelial cells were observed. What is the most probable diagnosis?

81c6b7ca-9838-416a-8174-15b5ee643a93.question: Patient diagnosed with acute diverticulitis, treated with amoxicillin/clavulanic acid. After 5 days, the patient starts to experience fever and diarrhea. The patient is diagnosed with Clostridium difficile colitis, the amoxicillin/clavulanic acid is discontinued, and metronidazole is prescribed. After 4 days, the patient has not responded to the metronidazole, but is clinically stable. The next step in the treatment is:

options.A: Change metronidazole to oral vancomycin (125 mg, four times a day for 10 days).
options.B: Change the metronidazole to piperacillin/tazobactam (4 g of piperacillin/0.5 g of tazobactam every 8 hours).
options.D: Perform a loop ileostomy with anterograde polyethylene glycol lavage.

3e462531-963f-4f98-a80b-69b44e291f45.question: An 82-year-old man comes to the emergency room due to constipation together with significant abdominal distension. In simple abdominal radiology, the coffee bean sign is observed, and in the barium enema, the bird's beak sign is seen. If there are no signs of gangrene or peritonitis, the treatment will begin with:

options.C: Segmental colectomy and laparoscopic colorectal anastomosis.
options.D: Surgical detorsion and pexy of sigmoid.

428b6b7b-6f8f-4421-afda-311b3875f135.question: The most common benign tumors of the esophagus are:

602883e2-3974-48d7-afea-1fa627cf2761.question: A 46-year-old patient underwent a Bilroth II gastrectomy for peptic ulcer a year ago. He presents with epigastric pain and upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Ulcers are detected in both the stomach and small intestine during the endoscopy. After stimulation with IV secretin, no significant increase in serum gastrin is observed. The situation most likely corresponds to:

af033753-acfa-4da4-923d-b0e9ad10d34a.question: The total mesorectal excision combined with anterior rectal resection in the treatment of mid to low rectal cancer aims to:

options.A: Perform an anastomosis with greater ease.
options.C: Decrease the number of local recurrences.

cf1acd86-ee29-4370-9097-b2ecb273710f.question: A 52-year-old woman who had a hysterectomy years ago due to a uterine fibroid, seeks consultation for distal constipation and a bulge in the posterior vaginal wall that increases during defecation maneuvers, having to insert a finger in the vagina to achieve defecation. The examination shows a 3rd degree rectocele. In magnetic resonance imaging, a descent of the vaginal vault together with the rectocele is observed. The most appropriate surgical treatment is:

options.B: Intervention to reinforce the rectovaginal septum via the transanal route (Khubchandani technique).
options.C: Transperineal intervention with placement of mesh in the recto-vaginal septum.

9f8c10c9-5ce5-45df-9358-faa1fffb1ee3.question: The surgical treatment of choice for vascular compression of the duodenum, also known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome or Wilkie's syndrome, is:

options.A: The division of the Treitz ligament.
options.C: The change in the position of the duodenum.
options.D: The bypass of the superior mesenteric artery.

2905a3e4-c67a-4ac9-884e-55873ebb73a0.question: Central diabetes insipidus is characterized by:

options.B: Plasma and urinary hypotonicity, polydipsia and polyuria with nocturia.
options.C: Inappropriate response to the administration of vasopressin.
options.D: Sodium levels in the high range of normal with urinary hypotonicity.

16e91619-2161-42e6-aff0-ab8b5bef0bd2.question: Central adrenal insufficiency due to the suppression of the hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis by the administration of corticosteroids:

options.A: It is the most common cause of adrenal insufficiency.
options.B: The dosage and duration of corticotherapy are not directly associated with the risk of adrenal insufficiency after its discontinuation.
options.C: The administration of corticoids suppresses the secretion of ACTH but does not affect the secretion of CRH.
options.D: The resolution of adrenal insufficiency after chronic corticosterapy occurs 24-48 hours after the withdrawal of the drug.

a15773f3-ead4-4722-baf3-24aab840504e.question: Once a Cushing's syndrome has been confirmed by clinical and biochemical criteria, what is the essential test to determine its cause?:

options.C: Inferior petrosal sinus sampling and selective venous catheterization.
options.D: Magnetic resonance imaging of the hypothalamic-pituitary region.

a3a2835e-8a54-42c4-be47-1d9400b79279.question: Pituitary apoplexy is usually an endocrine emergency. Indicate the correct answer:

options.A: The patient presents with compressive symptoms, hypopituitarism and hyperprolactinemia due to sectioning of the pituitary stalk.
options.B: Ophthalmoplegia due to cranial nerve involvement spontaneously subsides.
options.C: In patients without alteration of the visual field, it is necessary to urgently perform transsphenoidal decompressive surgery.
options.D: The most common hormonal deficiency is that of the antidiuretic hormone.

736c352a-fdf0-4602-bb02-0e73c53c0e7b.question: In a patient with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease (eGFR 52 ml/min), it is recommended to add, for its cardiovascular benefit, after metformin:

07897fef-3b6f-4bc3-b099-c280885857ea.question: A 66-year-old woman has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus for three months. She has a BMI of 31 Kg/m2 and exhibits poor glycemic control despite implementing a program of non-pharmacological measures (healthy eating, exercise). Which of the following hypoglycemic drugs is associated with weight gain and should we avoid in this patient?:

options.C: Canagliflozin (inhibitor of the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 - SGLT2).
options.D: Liraglutide (agonist of the receptor for GLP-1).

599d21de-327d-4b8d-b732-dfa36270e52f.question: An 18-year-old patient consulted for edema. A complete analysis was performed showing proteinuria of 8 g/day without microhematuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hypercholesterolemia with normal renal function. Empirical corticosteroids were administered. After a month, the clinical picture has completely disappeared. What is your diagnostic hypothesis?

83af0a23-a734-40b3-a73e-b08d1d7ae0a3.question: In the case of a patient with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD G4, eGFR 20 ml/min) who goes to the emergency department due to general weakness and is found to have severe hyperkalemia (K 7 mEq/l) with electrocardiographic alterations. What would be the first measure to take?:

options.B: Placement of a catheter to start dialysis.

b0c931b8-f6a6-4b1f-b0e4-82f92ac35307.question: Which of the following statements is not characteristic of acute interstitial nephritis?:

options.A: It is often caused by drugs.
options.B: Proteinuria is usually within the nephrotic range.
options.D: The definitive diagnosis is established by kidney biopsy.

2b1b7e29-5785-44be-a051-dd4bc2c462d0.question: Which of the following urinary ions promotes the formation of urinary lithiasis?:

5cdb8818-15c4-4e26-b47d-4c72d3cfd0b3.question: In one of the following conditions, asymptomatic bacteriuria would not require treatment:

options.A: Children under 5 years old with vesicoureteral reflux.
options.D: Patients who need to undergo an endoscopic or surgical examination of the urinary tract.

1d75fe47-a5f7-482b-9e51-e44bd6323109.question: The most common cause of severe neutropenia (<500 neutrophils/microliter) is:

options.C: Iatrogenic due to administration of medications.
options.D: Due to hypersplenism developed in infections.

38e0947f-fe51-41b2-96e4-402559641506.question: A 19-year-old woman, with a family history of anemia, shows signs of chronic hemolytic anemia, with a negative direct Coombs test. What would be the most likely diagnosis?

c23140bf-f3bc-4643-9da4-e672331f1e05.question: A 70-year-old woman goes to the emergency room for asthenia. The physical examination reveals cutaneous-mucosal paleness with sub-jaundice conjunctiva, and a pansystolic murmur audible in all foci. Laboratory findings show hemoglobin 8 g/dl, MCV 100 fl, LDH 900 U/l, undetectable haptoglobin, and total bilirubin 3.5 mg/dl. An immunohematological test was requested. Indicate the correct response:

options.A: The most likely diagnosis is lead poisoning; we must request a 24-hour urine lead test.
options.B: This is a case of hemolytic anemia; to determine its nature, we must request a hemoglobin electrophoresis.
options.C: This refers to a hemolytic anemia; we need to request a direct Coombs test, which determines the presence of IgG and/or the C3 fraction of the complement on the red blood cell membrane.
options.D: This is a case of hemolytic anemia; we must request a direct Coombs test, which determines the presence of free IgG in plasma.

35c7dbca-032f-42f1-b856-84cdfef733c4.question: One of the following consequences cannot be directly attributed to immobility syndrome in the elderly patient:

9e94a106-61e8-4c1d-b692-247f4bd00d51.question: A 75-year-old man, in good health and who could be considered robust, seeks information about using some type of treatment to maintain his good health and physical condition. What would be the best recommendation for this patient?

05828be6-0512-4bde-8eb9-3ec3bac0f5a5.question: In the CT scan of the abdomen with intravenous contrast performed for the study of chronic pancreatitis, which of the following findings is typical of this disease?:

options.C: Increase in glandular enhancement in the arterial phase.

a05d4496-707f-4daf-abbe-aea83baaf5eb.question: In relation to encephalitis caused by N-methyl-D-Aspartate (NMDAR) receptor antibodies, indicate the incorrect answer:

options.B: In some cases, it can occur after an infection by the herpes simplex virus 1.
options.C: It does not affect children under 1 year of age.
options.D: The diagnosis is established by demonstrating the presence of anti-NMDAR antibodies in the CSF and serum.

372f5598-6dcf-416a-bdbe-e16ad8933d48.question: A 32-year-old woman with type 2A multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome (MEN-2A) and carrier of a RET mutation. A hypoechogenic nodule of 6 mm with calcifications inside is identified in a neck ultrasound. A total thyroidectomy and cervical lymph node dissection is decided. In the macroscopic study, a total of three nodules are identified, two in the right lobe of 5 and 6 mm, and one in the left lobe of 4 mm. In the microscopic study, the three lesions consist of a uniform proliferation of rounded cells that are arranged in a solid pattern and are accompanied by calcifications and amyloid deposits. The nuclei are not clear, nor do they show clefts or pseudo-inclusions. The immunohistochemical staining for synaptophysin is positive. Metastases are identified in the cervical lymph node dissection. What is the pathological diagnosis of the lesions identified in the total thyroidectomy?

051b8882-e74e-4b20-a1f5-3ce10e6cd3fd.question: A 25-year-old patient who had a motorcycle accident on a Friday night. They are transferred to the emergency room and diagnosed with abdominal trauma (negative eco-fast), mild head injury (Glasgow = 14), and a displaced intracapsular fracture of the right hip. Hemodynamically, they are stable. What would be the treatment of choice?

options.A: Reduction, open if necessary, and osteosynthesis of the fracture in the first 24-36 hours.
options.B: Scheduled total arthroplasty for hip resurfacing on Monday.
options.C: Wait for improvement from the head trauma and schedule a regulated surgery for the following week, which consists of the reduction and osteosynthesis of the fracture.
options.D: In response to the risk of non-consolidation of these types of fractures, I would urgently implant a bipolar hemiarthroplasty of the hip.

90a9b1a2-0f83-4139-913b-bc1cf785ce3d.question: A 33-year-old patient, non-smoker, with a history of pneumothorax on two occasions, comes to the clinic with progressive dyspnea. The chest X-ray shows a left pleural effusion that occupies 1/3 of the hemithorax and multiple cystic images evenly distributed throughout both lungs. In the spirometry, she presents an FEV1/FVC of 64% and a diffusion test with a TLCO of 50%. Indicate the most likely diagnosis:

b7453db2-09eb-45ff-830d-8c9f25a60300.question: A class I recommendation in a clinical practice guideline means that:

options.A: It is based on scientific evidence from clinical trials.
options.B: There is evidence or agreement that following the recommendation has more benefits than harms for patients.
options.C: All patients who follow the recommendation will improve their health level.
options.D: That the recommended intervention has a high cost.

d34d560f-b92a-4b20-9bfc-293c00bc5e2b.question: A 37-year-old male presents with asthenia, low-grade fever (37.6ºC), and weight loss of about 5 kg over a 2-month period. In the last 2 weeks, there is an addition of burning paresthesias and hypoesthesia in all four limbs, as well as non-painful palpable purpuric lesions on both legs and feet. Blood pressure, kidney function, and urine sediment are normal. What would be the complementary test to confirm the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: A Doppler ultrasound of the renal arteries for the diagnosis of Takayasu's arteritis.
options.B: A "punch" (cookie cutter) type skin biopsy for the diagnosis of a polyarteritis nodosa.
options.C: The detection of circulating cryoglobulins for the diagnosis of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis.
options.D: A kidney biopsy for the diagnosis of an IgA vasculitis.

18e4c841-76f3-465f-8484-287a851441a3.question: A patient admitted for an opportunistic systemic mycosis is prescribed an antifungal drug with a narrow therapeutic index. The active form of the drug is excreted unmetabolized in urine by 60%. The patient suffers from severe renal failure, with a creatinine clearance of 20 ml/min. If the usual dosing schedule for the antifungal is 40 mg/kg/10 h, which of the following schedules is more suitable?:

options.A: 40 mg/kg/10 h (no dosage adjustment is required).
options.B: 30 mg/kg/10 h (the dose is only reduced to 30 mg/kg).
options.C: 30 mg/kg/20 h (the dose is reduced to 30 mg/kg and the interval between doses is extended to 20 h).
options.D: 40 mg/kg/20 h (only the interval between doses is extended to 20 h).

94c5994e-34df-46e5-91aa-f8ceeb95ddc2.question: In a patient known to have had a negative Mantoux test a few years ago, there is a turnaround of the same. The first reaction:

be0fb831-7960-4998-9e87-9a1e7ffdbd7d.question: Regarding plasma proteins, indicate the incorrect statement:

options.A: Albumin is synthesized in the liver and metabolized in numerous tissues, allowing them to utilize the amino acids derived from its degradation.
options.B: Albumin is the major protein in plasma, thus participating in the maintenance of oncotic pressure.
options.C: Albumin is involved in the transport of direct or conjugated bilirubin, as well as fatty acids, calcium, and some vitamins, hormones, and drugs.
options.D: Given the numerous genetic variants of albumin, it is possible to observe a double band of albumin in a proteinogram, which is known as bisalbuminemia, but which lacks clinical significance.

ce95297d-4053-46e0-8c08-068490c1032d.question: In relation to the pentose phosphate pathway (also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt), indicate the correct answer:

options.A: The first reaction of the non-oxidative branch of this pathway is the transformation of glucose 6-phosphate by glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase.
options.B: When the cell only requires NADPH (reduced form of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate), the pentose 5-phosphate from the pathway is recycled to glucose 6-phosphate through a biotin-dependent carboxylation.
options.C: Abnormal forms of glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase with lower catalytic activity severely affect tissues because they lack alternative mechanisms to synthesize NADPH or to induce the synthesis of the enzyme.
options.D: The production of NADPH through this pathway particularly protects red blood cells from oxidative aggression.

685544d7-7edc-4784-8aba-66806a441bbd.question: To determine whether the regular use of acetylsalicylic acid is associated with a higher risk of hypertension, a group of subjects is selected, it is found out how many are taking acetylsalicylic acid and they are followed for 5 years to identify new cases of hypertension. Indicate the correct answer about the design of this study:

options.A: It is a clinical trial because it is carried out with drugs.
options.B: It is an ecological study because many subjects are followed.
options.C: It is a case-control study, in which the cases take aspirin and the controls do not.
options.D: It's a cohort study, because subjects are followed according to their exposure to identify the risk of a disease.

26eef034-c4e2-4085-bb6c-195995923241.question: In a population, 2,000 fatal traffic accidents occurred from January 1st to December 31st, 2019. What measure of accident frequency has been used?

dcaa44a5-32a6-4ac2-bcb8-32220eca52ad.question: Of the following criteria for causality in a statistical association between an exposure and an outcome, which is the only necessary one?:

3ba2a860-b9b3-4279-9d47-686750f36c76.question: Regarding the relative risk, indicate the incorrect answer:

options.A: It is the ratio between the cumulative incidence in the exposed population and the cumulative incidence in the non-exposed population.
options.D: For its proper interpretation, it is necessary to know its confidence interval.

dbd055f7-f013-4ed4-951e-5f955744203b.question: Of the five recommended moments in hand hygiene, indicate the incorrect answer:

options.C: Before contact with the patient's environment.
options.D: After contact with the patient's environment.

bb61ef9c-3242-4308-9992-dacb61be525f.question: Among the precautions to be taken in droplet isolation, the following are excluded:

options.C: The door of the room can remain open.
options.D: Place a surgical mask on the patient if it is necessary to move them out of the room.

f513d34c-338a-4666-9b8e-bf3d838102dd.question: We inform the management of our hospital that the incidence density of infection in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) is 15 per thousand and they ask us what that figure means. Our response should be:

options.A: If there were 1,000 patients admitted to the ICU, there would be 15 new infections every day.
options.B: For every 1,000 admissions to the hospital, 15 get infected in the ICU.
options.C: The daily risk of admission to the ICU is 15 per 1,000 inhabitants in the reference population.
options.D: 15 out of every 1,000 patients admitted to the ICU get infected.

88ef26d4-6ba3-47f1-a349-879ceab1f777.question: A pregnant woman comes to the consultation for hypercholesterolemia. Which drug will be contraindicated due to the high risk of fetal anomalies demonstrated in humans, exceeding its possible therapeutic benefit?:

4514aca8-f23a-494d-b5fd-33fdbd74b8e4.question: When dealing with a patient with Parkinson's disease who is experiencing nausea at the start of treatment with dopaminergic agonists, which drug would you use to improve this symptom?

bec5cd95-61d1-4d6e-9cba-d13111aecdc6.question: One of the following drugs is specific for preventing the onset of non-convulsive generalized epileptic seizures by blocking T-type calcium channels. Indicate which one:

96c4cb18-745b-44ff-8ac8-ea2fb07f555a.question: If we use a repeated administration regimen with a drug that has a half-life of 8 hours, the steady-state plasma concentration will be reached:

options.A: After 16 hours from the start of administration.
options.B: 24 hours after the start of administration.
options.C: After 32 hours from the start of administration.
options.D: After 40 hours from the start of administration.

91781a41-f583-477d-bac4-50858f1ef688.question: In relation to the control of coronary blood flow, it is false that:

options.A: If the strength of the heart contraction increases, the speed of the coronary flow also increases.
options.B: In the presence of very low concentrations of oxygen in the myocytes, the availability of adenosine increases.
options.C: The direct effect of coronary sympathetic activation can cause both vasoconstriction and vasodilation.
options.D: The direct and indirect effects of the parasympathetic coronary activity (vagal) cause vasodilation of the coronary arteries.

6ff7a66e-db90-4088-90e5-315b9f38518d.question: Indicate which of the following factors causes an increase in the amount of oxygen released by hemoglobin:

219a3fbd-237a-4abe-b78a-f6242b20de48.question: The process of genetic anticipation, whereby the clinical manifestations of a disease become more severe as it passes from one generation to another, is usually a consequence of:

options.A: Accumulation of point mutations in a gene as generations pass.
options.B: Accumulation of point mutations in several genes of the same pathway as generations pass.

e1c567a5-6973-4fb1-9419-ae664f4dd520.question: A 15-year-old girl who shows a delay in menarche and is short in stature. She does not have an intellectual disability. Which of the following genetic tests would typically be used for the diagnosis of this patient?:

49357683-66cb-4b6d-bccf-6c1d3c478a4c.question: In the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease, humanized monoclonal antibodies can be used that are targeted against TNF-alpha (such as adalimumab) or against the integrin a4ß7 (such as vedolizumab). Regarding the integrin a4ß7 (also called LPAM-1), it is true that:

options.A: It binds to ICAM-1 and is responsible for the passage of lymphocytes from the peripheral blood to the lymph nodes.
options.B: It is a receptor for TNF-a in CD4+ T lymphocytes of the mucosa-associated lymphoid system.
options.C: It is expressed in the cells of the gastrointestinal epithelium in patients with inflammatory bowel disease.
options.D: It binds to the adhesin MadCAM-1 and promotes the passage of lymphocytes from the peripheral blood to the Peyer's patches and the intestinal lamina propria.

69491a9f-8ebe-4a42-9eef-d7523a84bebd.question: The Ministry of Health recommends that during the third trimester of pregnancy, women should be revaccinated against Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough. Why?:

options.A: For the mother's immune system to produce IgM isotype antibodies, specific against the pathogen, which allow both her and the fetus to be immunized.
options.B: So that the mother's immune system produces IgG isotype antibodies, specific against the pathogen, that allow the baby to be passively immunized after birth.
options.C: In order for the fetus's immune system to produce IgM and IgG isotype antibodies, specific against the pathogen, which allow the baby to be actively immunized after birth.
options.D: For the mother's immune system to produce memory T lymphocytes, which cross the placenta and allow the baby to be passively immunized after birth.

d477ae90-fd50-4592-8c1c-2265208965f7.question: In a 40-year-old woman, not pregnant and with no relevant pathological history, diagnosed with intermittent mild-moderate allergic rhinitis due to sensitization to grass pollens, which of the following symptomatic treatments is the first choice?:

options.A: Oral hydroxyzine and ipratropium bromide (nasal spray).
options.C: Oral dexchlorpheniramine and topical nasal cromoglycate.
options.D: Oral Ketotifen and topical nasal Oxymetazoline.

de8b0f33-811a-420c-b3c1-02362c8aec2a.question: A 60-year-old man undergoing treatment with carbamazepine for epilepsy, presenting with fever (38.8°C), odynophagia (painful swallowing), conjunctivitis, brownish skin lesions spread over a large part of the body surface, similar to a target in appearance, and accompanied by epidermal detachment (over 30%) at the slightest touch. It is highly likely that he is showing clinical signs of:

options.A: Acute urticaria caused by pharmacological reasons.
options.B: Minor exudative erythema secondary to drugs.

428f4b21-6158-4605-88fd-2474869a9e19.question: All of the following are causes of metastatic calcification except:

22b5c76b-3862-4a54-b289-8c586f1300e2.question: The vasopressor of choice to maintain perfusion pressure in a patient with septic shock is:

29f748bc-b20f-445e-bb60-4b729fe2509f.question: During general anesthesia, the patient's temperature has been progressively increasing and you come to the conclusion that they are suffering from malignant hyperthermia. Regarding this complication, one of the following statements is true:

options.A: It is caused by the use of halogenated anesthetics and non-depolarizing muscle relaxants. It should be treated with benzodiazepines.
options.B: It is caused by the use of barbiturates and opioids. It should be treated with dantrolene.
options.C: It is caused by the use of halogenated anesthetics and depolarizing muscle relaxants. It should be treated with dantrolene.
options.D: It is caused by the use of ketamine and local anesthetics. There is no treatment.

8ff66469-6fce-4957-a103-02ba6d2ebfdf.question: Which of the following functions does not correspond to the Healthcare Ethics Committees?:

options.A: Conduct the mandatory ethical counseling of a clinical trial with human beings.
options.B: Advise on clinical cases with complex ethical dilemmas where careful deliberation is recommended.
options.C: Explore the training needs in the field of bioethics of the professionals at the institution.
options.D: Advise patients or family members who consult about an ethical issue in relation to healthcare.

dc66621c-3e49-4747-9efd-beaec002634a.question: Regarding the tumors of the salivary glands:

options.A: The adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common tumor of the salivary glands and typically settles in the parotid gland.
options.B: The adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common tumor of the salivary glands and typically settles in the submaxillary gland.
options.C: The pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the salivary glands and typically settles in the parotid gland.
options.D: The pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the salivary glands and typically settles in the submandibular gland.

d7f1df6b-aeeb-4bbd-916a-86770683d5ed.question: Regarding the reconstruction of the smile in patients with facial paralysis, we can affirm that:

options.A: It is not recommended to perform a dynamic reconstruction without previously performing a static reconstruction.
options.B: Dynamic reconstruction involves performing a neurotized muscle transfer.
options.C: Static reconstruction is indicated in cases where facial paralysis has been established for less than a year.
options.D: Direct nerve sutures from a motor nerve to the damaged facial nerve can be performed in the first few months after the facial nerve injury occurs.

c7f3b722-61c2-40df-bdac-6777963d1ccd.question: In relation to the powerful opioid analgesics commonly used to treat severe pain in patients with advanced irreversible chronic disease, indicate the incorrect answer:

options.A: Fentanyl should be adjusted in case of renal insufficiency.
options.B: Morphine has a half-life of 4 hours.
options.C: Oxycodone has a lower incidence of nausea than morphine.

ca250855-e6ea-453f-8001-07d138c533e7.question: In the case of a patient who is in a terminal state, with a life expectancy of less than a month, and who presents with intense anorexia, indicate which of the following treatments you think is most appropriate to treat this symptom:

41824e21-83a1-4750-bb74-c9dafc2a2aa7.question: Of the following methods, which is the most reliable for estimating the post-mortem interval in the early period after death?

options.A: Quantification of potassium in vitreous humor.
options.B: Observation of the evolution of post-mortem lividity.
options.D: Assessment of ocular reactivity to acetylcholine eye drops.

95572745-6554-4201-ac78-a5eb8c2e7424.question: In a minor patient, all the following infections should be suspected as being caused by sexual contact, once perinatal transmission has been ruled out. Only one of them probably has a non-sexual origin in little girls. Please specify which one:

options.C: Molluscum contagiosum of the genital area.

6b35f1fa-637e-463b-a54e-d41b422bc1e2.question: What would be the treatment for a 31-year-old patient, nulliparous and asymptomatic, who was diagnosed with a lesion consistent with a 4 cm right ovarian endometrioma on a routine ultrasound?

options.A: Gynecological examination and regulated ultrasound study for deep endometriosis screening.
options.B: Diagnostic-therapeutic laparoscopy for confirmation and extent of disease diagnosis.
options.D: Initiation of treatment with gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) analogues to prevent disease progression.

8c100f06-337e-4b49-a837-cce8603636f8.question: What is the most important sonographic marker in the screening of aneuploidies in the first trimester of pregnancy?

options.B: The alteration of the venous duct wave.
options.C: The presence of choroid plexus cysts.

413f89f1-4470-44ff-b5c8-3e8f4d44a949.question: The following parameters, except one, are routine data for periodic control in premature rupture of membranes in a preterm pregnancy. Indicate which one:

options.C: Complete blood count and determination of C-reactive protein.

fd7fc47d-70d9-4783-8a69-3e5400de9036.question: 65-year-old woman without comorbidities, who undergone conservative surgery of the left breast with selective biopsy of the sentinel node. The pathological anatomy of the specimen shows a grade III infiltrating ductal carcinoma of 11 mm, two negative sentinel nodes, estrogen receptors: 0%, progesterone receptors: 0%, Ki 67: 70%, HER2: negative. The extension study is negative. The adjuvant treatment would be:

options.A: Anthracycline and taxane-based chemotherapy, radiotherapy and trastuzumab.
options.B: Chemotherapy based on anthracyclines and taxanes, radiation therapy and tamoxifen.
options.C: Chemotherapy based on anthracyclines and taxanes, and radiotherapy.
options.D: Anthracycline and taxane-based chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and aromatase inhibitors, since she is postmenopausal.

a98b63bc-87d1-4aac-a3eb-2b5333be19ed.question: A 30-year-old woman comes to your clinic because she has noticed a lump in her right breast that has recently appeared. Her grandmother had breast cancer. Upon examination, a 2.5 cm nodule with regular edges is palpated in the upper-outer quadrant. She has no previous imaging tests. Indicate the correct answer:

options.A: Requests a mammary ultrasound given the patient's age.
options.B: Requests a mammogram because it is the "gold standard" diagnostic test.
options.C: Requests a magnetic resonance imaging given the patient's age and family history.
options.D: He explains to her that, being 30 years old, it is probably a cyst and will opt for a clinical check-up in 6-12 months. If it persists, then he will request an imaging test.

382e2bd1-9258-42dc-a951-c9123efadcec.question: A first-time mother at 40+2 weeks presents to the emergency room with obvious amniotic fluid leakage and regular contractions. Prenatal follow-up has been normal, and she has tested positive for Group B streptococcus in a vaginal-rectal swab. On obstetric examination, her cervix is 5 cm dilated, 80% effaced, and centered, with a single fetus in a head-down presentation. What would be the recommended course of action for this patient?

options.A: Hospital admission in obstetrics ward and observation.
options.B: Return home and antibiotic prophylaxis with penicillin during expulsion period.
options.C: Assessment in outpatient obstetrics consultations for the performance of obstetric ultrasound and fetal Doppler.
options.D: Hospital admission in dilation room and antibiotic prophylaxis with penicillin.

98a46010-4503-474b-9cfb-90e76c3699e3.question: A 34-year-old woman diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome has been dealing with primary infertility for 2 years and has been unsuccessfully treated for 6 months with clomiphene citrate (100 mg/day for 5 days). She has not associated other causes of infertility. What would be the most appropriate treatment at this point?

options.B: Increase the dosage of clomiphene citrate to 200 mg/day for 5 days, for an additional 6 months.

5417046e-0d48-4122-958f-d7cdefcdfa49.question: What genetic and reproductive advice would you give to a 30-year-old woman who consults because she is a carrier of a premutation in the FMR1 gene, responsible for fragile X chromosome syndrome, and wants to have offspring? Indicate the correct answer:

options.A: All their male children will be carriers and, therefore, will manifest the disease.
options.B: There is a phenomenon of genetic anticipation, so their offspring will present more severe and earlier symptoms.
options.C: Preimplantation genetic diagnosis for sex selection of embryos through fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) is the best option for having healthy offspring.
options.D: 50% of his daughters will be carriers, but they will not show clinical manifestations of the disease.

da020f28-8dfa-4787-9103-f11e5223b5e5.question: A myopic 83-year-old man is being treated for diabetes and hypertension. His family brings him to a consultation because in the past few days, he has been spilling his glass of water on the table and hitting his head on the kitchen furniture multiple times, although he does not report any visual deficit. The intraocular pressure is 18 mmHg in both eyes and visual acuity is 0.9 in both eyes. What would be the correct response?

options.A: Treatment with prostaglandin analogs in eye drops must be initiated, because there is normal tension glaucoma with visual field impairment.
options.B: This could be a case of cortical blindness and a visual field test should be conducted to assess a possible homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing.
options.C: As he does not report any visual problems, has normal intraocular pressure and normal visual acuity, these are normal oversights for his age.
options.D: The patient has a peripheral retinal detachment secondary to their myopia, which has not yet affected the posterior pole.

f89b2621-bd05-4e89-b20b-38b0a64bcdb4.question: A 67-year-old woman has been experiencing luminescent flashes in her left eye when she moves her head for the past three days, mainly at night. As of this morning, she has noticed a dark area that moves with her gaze. Visual acuity is 1.0 in both eyes. What would be the correct approach?

options.A: A visual field test must be carried out to confirm the presence of a posterior vitreous detachment, as this is the only way to distinguish a posterior vitreous detachment from a retinal detachment.
options.B: The presence of phosphenes is a pathognomonic sign of posterior vitreous detachment, which should be treated with pneumatic retinopexy.
options.C: The appearance of phosphenes followed by a dark spot that moves with the gaze suggests a posterior vitreous detachment, although a fundus examination should be carried out to rule out a retinal tear or vitreous hemorrhage.
options.D: An ocular hypotensive treatment must be established, as the patient has suffered acute glaucoma which was caused by the flashes and visual field alterations due to nerve damage are appearing today.

8384cb10-a682-4e77-ac25-beae75d41767.question: A 40-year-old patient, with a normal physical examination, in whom a mediastinal mass and a hepatic nodule have been revealed in the computed tomography, and in the analysis an elevation of serum lactic dehydrogenase (LDH), human chorionic betagonadotropin (beta-HCG) and alpha-fetoprotein in the blood. What is your diagnostic suspicion?

options.D: Metastatic extragonadal nonseminomatous germ cell cancer.

5ebaf0c6-82c4-4af6-9661-be4e9de3fd41.question: In a patient with lung cancer without comorbidity, the combination of chemotherapy and radiotherapy is the first-choice treatment in:

52b4c268-cd6e-4471-9589-c2d323dcfe2e.question: Radiation therapy in breast cancer is not indicated in:

c4be9b5d-c5f6-4cfb-a5fd-ed68b83c30ba.question: A 27-year-old healthy man, presented with intense pain in his right ear that worsens with pressure on the tragus, purulent discharge, feeling of blockage, itchiness, and a certain degree of hearing loss for several hours duration. Otoscopic examination verifies the presence of ear discharge and significant inflammatory signs in the external auditory canal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

9df40aab-59bf-4200-aa41-627075d31aaf.question: Indicate the most sensitive examination method to establish the diagnosis of sinusitis, study the anatomy of the osteomeatal complex, and identify possible complications due to local spread of the infection:

f0842aeb-8f06-487e-961f-dc591969d725.question: A 5-year-old boy diagnosed with chronic renal failure. He goes to the emergency room due to vomiting, general discomfort, and palpitations. An electrocardiogram is performed where elevated T waves stand out and blood analysis with potassium levels of 5.9 mEq/L. Immediate administration of calcium gluconate is decided. What is the objective of this treatment?:

options.A: Promote the displacement of potassium from the plasma space to the intracellular space.
options.B: Decrease the circulating potassium to promote its hepatic elimination.
options.C: Chelate the circulating potassium to promote its renal elimination.
options.D: Antagonize the action of potassium on the myocardial cell membrane.

9ae211f4-db5e-44b1-8431-cb5007f303f5.question: Infant of 6 months presented to the emergency room due to respiratory difficulty. Examination: axillary temperature 37.2°C, respiratory rate 40 rpm, heart rate 160 bpm, blood pressure 90/45 mmHg, SatO2 95% with room air. Shows moderate respiratory difficulty with intercostal and subcostal retraction. Lung auscultation: scattered expiratory wheezing, prolonged expiration and slight decrease in air entry in both lung fields. Heart auscultation: no murmurs. It is decided to keep the patient under observation in the hospital for a few hours. What is the most appropriate course of action to take at this point in terms of additional tests?:

options.A: Request venous blood gas, leukocyte count, and acute phase reactants.
options.C: Request arterial blood gas and acute phase reactants.

e0eb781f-e271-4d84-b850-7cd732e88ae1.question: The most common cause of permanent congenital hypothyroidism is:

options.A: The alteration in the embryonic development of the thyroid gland (thyroid dysgenesis).
options.B: Dyshormonogenesis (congenital errors in the synthesis/secretion of thyroid hormones).
options.D: The syndromes of resistance to thyroid hormones.

2c335949-08dc-4822-864f-1abd2e990bfe.question: Which of the following statements about autoimmune thyroiditis or Hashimoto's disease is incorrect?:

options.A: It is a pathology that can occur in childhood-adolescence.
options.B: Patients with Down syndrome (trisomy 21) have a higher incidence of autoimmune thyroiditis than the general population.
options.C: Autoimmune thyroiditis usually progresses towards hypothyroidism, but at the onset of the disease, patients may experience a transient phase of hyperthyroidism.
options.D: Patients with Turner syndrome (karyotype 45, X0) and Klinefelter syndrome (karyotype 47, XXY) have a lower incidence of autoimmune thyroiditis than the general population.

f2371f3c-0d52-4df2-b4c1-240ec6d5b094.question: 8-year-old boy who consults due to the appearance of pubic hair at the base of the penis for the past 12 months. The testicle has not increased in volume and the penis has not increased in size. No increase in growth rate is observed in the last year. The bone age is one year older than the chronological age. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
